Fitting models¶

The file fitmodels.py contains generic models used for fitting. Available models are listed below. In order to create own model, please add your model to userfitmodels.py. The other file was added so that the original file is not modified. For creating your own model, you can get inspiration from generic models in fitmodels.py.

In classical kinetic models, the concentration at time zero (\(c(0) = c_0\)) is omitted as a fitting parameter for \(1^{\mathrm{st}}\) order kinetics, because the rate does not depend on \(c_0\). This parameter is included for variable order and special models (eg. Photobleaching), because the rate depends on \(c_0\).

A→B (1st order)¶

class fitmodels.AB1stModel[source]¶

This is the A→B model, 1st order kinetics. Differential equations:

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{A}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = -k[\mathrm{A}]\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{B}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k[\mathrm{A}]\)

initial conditions: \([\mathrm A]_0 = c_0 \qquad [\mathrm B]_0 = 0\)

A→B (var order)¶

class fitmodels.ABVarOrderModel[source]¶

This is the A→B model, variable order kinetics. Differential equations:

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{A}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = -k[\mathrm{A}]^n\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{B}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k[\mathrm{A}]^n\)

initial conditions: \([\mathrm A]_0 = c_0 \qquad [\mathrm B]_0 = 0\)

A→B (Mixed 1st and 2nd order)¶

class fitmodels.AB_mixed12Model[source]¶

This is the A→B model, mixed 1st and 2nd order kinetics. Differential equations:

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{A}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = -k_1[\mathrm{A}] - k_2[\mathrm{A}]^2\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{B}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_1[\mathrm{A}] + k_2[\mathrm{A}]^2\)

initial conditions: \([\mathrm A]_0 = c_0 \qquad [\mathrm B]_0 = 0\)

A→B→C (1st order)¶

class fitmodels.ABC1stModel[source]¶

This is the A→B→C model, 1st order kinetics. Differential equations:

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{A}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = -k_1[\mathrm{A}]\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{B}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_1[\mathrm{A}] - k_2[\mathrm{B}]\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{C}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_2[\mathrm{B}]\)

initial conditions: \([\mathrm A]_0 = c_0 \qquad [\mathrm B]_0 = [\mathrm C]_0 = 0\)

A→B→C (var order)¶

class fitmodels.ABCvarOrderModel[source]¶

This is the A→B→C model, variable order kinetics. Differential equations:

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{A}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = -k_1[\mathrm{A}]^{n_1}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{B}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_1[\mathrm{A}]^{n_1} - k_2[\mathrm{B}]^{n_2}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{C}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_2[\mathrm{B}]^{n_2}\)

initial conditions: \([\mathrm A]_0 = c_0 \qquad [\mathrm B]_0 = [\mathrm C]_0 = 0\)

Note, that \(n_2\) must be \(\ge 1\), however, \(n_1 \ge 0\).

A→B→C→D (1st order)¶

class fitmodels.ABCD1stModel[source]¶

This is the A→B→C→D model, 1st order kinetics. Differential equations:

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{A}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = -k_1[\mathrm{A}]\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{B}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_1[\mathrm{A}] - k_2[\mathrm{B}]\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{C}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_2[\mathrm{B}] - k_3[\mathrm{C}]\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{D}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_3[\mathrm{C}]\)

initial conditions: \([\mathrm A]_0 = c_0 \qquad [\mathrm B]_0 = [\mathrm C]_0 = [\mathrm D]_0 = 0\)

A→B→C→D (var order)¶

class fitmodels.ABCDvarOrderModel[source]¶

This is the A→B→C→D model, variable order kinetics. Differential equations:

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{A}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = -k_1[\mathrm{A}]^{n_1}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{B}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_1[\mathrm{A}]^{n_1} - k_2[\mathrm{B}]^{n_2}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{C}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_2[\mathrm{B}]^{n_2} - k_3[\mathrm{C}]^{n_3}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{D}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_3[\mathrm{C}]^{n_3}\)

initial conditions: \([\mathrm A]_0 = c_0 \qquad [\mathrm B]_0 = [\mathrm C]_0 = [\mathrm D]_0 = 0\)

Note, that \(n_2,n_3\) must be \(\ge 1\), however, \(n_1 \ge 0\).

A→B, C→D (1st order)¶

class fitmodels.ABCD_seqModel[source]¶

This is the A→B, C→D sequential model, 1st order kinetics. Differential equations:

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{A}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = -k_1[\mathrm{A}]\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{B}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_1[\mathrm{A}]\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{C}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = -k_2[\mathrm{C}]\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}[\mathrm{D}]}{\mathrm{d}t} = +k_2[\mathrm{C}]\)

initial conditions are same as in A→B model, since it is a 1st order, \(c_0\) was not added to the parameters.

Linear¶

class fitmodels.LinearModel[source]¶

This is the linear model, \(y(x) = ax + y_0\) where \(a\) is a slope and \(y_0\) intercept.

Photobleaching¶

class fitmodels.Photobleaching_Model[source]¶

This is the photobleaching model. Differential equation:

\(\frac{\mathrm{d}c(t)}{\mathrm{d}t} = -k\left(1 - 10^{-\varepsilon c(t)l}\right)\)

where \(k = \frac{1}{V}I_0\Phi\) is a product of incident light intensity and photoreaction quantum yield divided by the volume of the solution.

initial conditions: \(c(0) = c_0 = \frac{A_0}{\varepsilon l}\)

Integrated law for evolution of absorbance in time (fitting equation):

\(A(t) = \frac{1}{\ln 10}\ln\left( 10^{-A_0k^{\prime}t} \left( 10^{A_0} + 10^{A_0k^{\prime}t} - 1 \right)\right)\)

where \(A_0\) is absorbance at time 0, \(k^{\prime} = \frac{k}{c_0}\), both \(k\) and \(c_0\) are fitting parameters, one of them must be fixed, usually \(c_0\)
